content.notes: Content not refactored in Phase 1; original preserved under payload.

payload.posterTitle: North America: Fire Springs, Wild Water, and High Country

biomes.name: Yellowstone Plateau
biomes.description: Yellowstone sits on powerful heat below the ground. Geysers, hot springs, and steaming basins share space with forests and meadows where bison, elk, and wolves move through a living landscape.

biomes.name: Chihuahuan Desert
biomes.description: The Chihuahuan Desert is a high, dry region of rugged mountains and wide basins. Cacti, agaves, and tough shrubs survive heat, wind, and sudden storms across this desert grassland.

biomes.name: Canadian Boreal Forest
biomes.description: Canada’s boreal forest is a vast belt of spruce, pine, bogs, and lakes. It stores huge amounts of carbon and provides habitat for moose, bears, wolves, and migrating birds.

biomes.name: Belize Barrier Reef
biomes.description: Belize’s barrier reef runs along warm, clear water filled with coral gardens. Sea turtles, rays, and bright fish weave through the reef, while mangroves and seagrass protect the coast.

biomes.name: Bay of Fundy
biomes.description: The Bay of Fundy has the world’s highest tides. Water rises and falls dramatically each day, feeding rich coastal ecosystems and carving cliffs, beaches, and sea stacks along the shore.

biomes.name: Greenland Ice Sheet
biomes.description: Greenland’s ice sheet is a massive cap of compacted snow and ice. It feeds glaciers that calve into the sea, and its meltwater shapes rivers, lakes, and blue channels on the surface.

biomes.name: Rocky Mountains
biomes.description: The Rocky Mountains form a long backbone of peaks, forests, and alpine valleys. Snowpack feeds major rivers, while elk, bears, and eagles thrive across rugged high country.
